awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Toward Large Scale Manufacturing and Engineering of Two-Dimensional Electronics
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this program is to develop a robust and scalable vapor phase based manufacturing and engineering strategy to produce wafer-scale high quality MoS2 atomic layers, a highly promising 2D semiconductor, and their in-plane hybrids with graphene and h-BN towards high performance and extremely compact 2D electronic devices. A systematic quality evaluation procedure including structural, electrical and mechanical characterizations will also be established, followed by detailed device characterizations to provide critical feedbacks for the manufacturing and engineering process. 

The intellectual merit is to realize the potential of large scale manufacturing and rational engineering of several emerging 2D materials for future 2D electronic device applications. It is very exciting to be able to control the domain shapes and sizes of several in-plane heterostructures through atomic layer engineering. In fact, with the appropriate selection of atomic layers of materials with different electronic properties, entire devices could be engineered and fabricated within a single atomic layer, bringing a completely new dimension to device technologies and representing a truly transformative advancement for future electronics.

The broader impacts are promoting interdisciplinary research and educational efforts integration from physics, chemistry and engineering communities in the next decade. Graduate students and/or post-doctoral fellows will be positively impacted as they will be undertaking important research assignments in this project. Cross-boundary educational efforts, due to the nature of this research, would be strongly encouraged to train talents who would contribute to scientific discovery and engineering innovation in this emerging field in US.

Project Outcomes Report

ECCS-1327093: EAGER: Toward Large Scale Manufacturing and Engineering

of Two-Dimensional Electronics

Jun Lou and Pulickel Ajayan (Rice)

 

Driven by the quest for ultimate miniaturization, two-dimensional (2D) electronics which have the entire device built within a single atomic layer have recently shown great promises. However, practical applications of such devices in future applications require the development of high-quality, large scale fabrication and engineering strategies enabling facile integration of all the components in 2D electronics.

 

The research activities in this project represent a vital step towards rational engineering of several emerging 2D materials for future 2D electronic device applications. In short two years, we were able to reach several important milestones as summarized below. First, we have studied the effects of interface chemistry and the important device physics concerning contacts for CVD-grown MoS2 monolayers. Second, we have carried out studies on enhancing the photocurrent and photoluminescence (PL) of MoS2 monolayers by integrating resonant plasmonic nanoshells. Third, we have investigated the potential of vapor phase grown large-area MoS2 atomic layers with artificially created active sites for photo-electrochemical applications. Fourth, we have demonstrated the atomic processes of cleaving MoS2 atomic layers inside a transmission electron microscope (TEM). Fifth, we have successfully fabricated an avalanche photodector in InSe atomic layers. Finally, we have demonstrated the scalable transfer of suspended 2D crystals, paving the way for large-scale device fabrications.

 

This project has attracted two female undergraduate students who wanted to have research experiences in nanomaterials related field. Both students are either currently in graduate school or applying for graduate school in the related field.  Several special topic discussion sessions integrating the research activity pursued in this project were also created in a graduate course MSCI 650 “Nanomaterials and Nanomechanics” taught by the PI in spring 2014 and 2015. With the research developed in this project, we are able to make bigger impact to society and U.S. economy by training highly qualified and skilled work-force to keep the U.S. leading position in this growing industry.
